title: Improving Child Speech Recognition and Reading Mistake Detection by Using Prompts
author: Lingyun Gao (Centre for Language Studies, Radboud University), Cristian Tejedor-Garcia (Centre for Language Studies, Radboud University), Catia Cucchiarini (Centre for Language Studies, Radboud University), Helmer Strik (Centre for Language Studies, Radboud University), ...
relevance_why: This paper introduces prompting methods that enhance speech recognition and reading mistake detection, which can be applied to improve audio-based applications in education and potentially benefit generative audio technologies being developed by Haohe Liu.
background: The study focuses on automatically evaluating children's reading aloud performance using speech recognition systems and prompts to detect reading mistakes.
contribution: This paper introduces a multimodal approach combining Whisper and large language models with prompts to improve child speech recognition and reading mistake detection, achieving significant performance enhancements.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Prior speech recognition models primarily struggled with child speech and reading evaluations, focusing on accurate transcription without effectively detecting reading mistakes.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances the recognition capability by utilizing text prompts and a hybrid prompting approach that integrates audio context with advanced language models.

key_innovation: The novel use of irrelevant text with generated mistakes as prompts significantly improves the transcription and detection of reading errors.
real_world_impact: This research could lead to advancements in educational tools facilitating better monitoring of children's reading skills, potentially increasing literacy rates and providing automated feedback mechanisms.
limitations: The study does not mention further challenges regarding scalability to other languages or broad applicability outside the specific dataset used.

new_terms.Word Error Rate (WER): **Word Error Rate (WER)** is a common metric for evaluating speech recognition accuracy, calculated as the number of errors (insertions, deletions, substitutions) divided by the total number of words spoken.
